title: Financial Fairness
description: Assess how fair and equitable your financial dynamic feels

questions.text: I feel our financial dynamic is fair, given our circumstances.

therapeutic.rationale: Perceived fairness matters more than strict equality. Partners who feel the arrangement is fair—whatever form that takes—experience less resentment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: A fairness gap is significant. The partner who feels it's unfair needs to articulate what would feel more equitable.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense of fairness creates stability in your financial relationship.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does 'fair' look like to you financially? Is that what you have?

questions.text: I don't feel financial pressure or obligation from my partner.

therapeutic.rationale: Financial pressure in a relationship can feel controlling or create resentment. Healthy partnerships avoid using money as leverage.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner feels pressure, explore what's creating that feeling. Sometimes it's unspoken expectations rather than explicit demands.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual freedom from financial pressure creates a healthier dynamic.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you ever feel financially pressured in your relationship? What creates that?

questions.text: I believe income differences don't create power imbalance between us.

therapeutic.rationale: Income differences are common but can create unhealthy dynamics if the higher earner holds more power. Healthy couples separate earning from decision-making authority.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different perceptions of power balance need attention. The partner feeling less powerful may be experiencing something the other doesn't see.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared perception that income doesn't equal power creates equality in your partnership.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Does earning more or less affect how decisions get made in your relationship?

questions.text: I feel respected regardless of my financial contribution.

therapeutic.rationale: Respect shouldn't depend on financial contribution. Partners who feel valued regardless of income bring their full selves to the relationship.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner feels less respected due to finances, this needs immediate attention. Respect is foundational.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual respect regardless of financial contribution creates a secure partnership.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Does your financial contribution—or your partner's—affect how respected you feel?

questions.text: I believe we would adjust fairly if our financial situations changed.

therapeutic.rationale: Confidence that your dynamic would adapt to changes—job loss, career change, illness—reflects trust in your partnership's flexibility and fairness.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doubts adaptability, explore what concerns them. Is it based on observed rigidity or past experiences?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared confidence in adapting fairly to changes creates security about your future.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How would your financial dynamic need to change if circumstances shifted dramatically?
